head.title: Merit Test Is Divisive in Affirmative Action Case; Flip a Coin

hedline.hl1: Merit Test Is Divisive in Affirmative Action Case; Flip a Coin

abstract.p: Craig J Cantoni letter notes that Bob Herbert's Oct 5 column on Piscataway, New Jersey, teacher case illustrates double standards; notes that EEOC actually forbids using educational achievement as factor in decisions, to deal with problem of minorities having less formal education; adds it is no wonder there is backlash against affirmative action (S)

block.p: Bob Herbert's Oct. 5 column on the Piscataway, N.J., case serves as a perfect example of the complexities, contradictions and double standards of affirmative action.

Mr. Herbert suggests that the black teacher should have retained her job over the white teacher because she has a master's degree. Unfortunately, under Equal Employment Opportunity Commission guidelines and legal precedent, educational achievement cannot be used as a factor in hiring, promotion or retention decisions unless it is a bona fide occupational qualification. Except for technical specialties, it is very difficult and expensive to prove that educational level is a valid occupational qualification.
